structured_data.name: GHS-BUILT R2015B
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (e.g., GHS_BUILT_ LDSMT_GLOBE_R2015B_3857_38, GHS_BUILT_LDS1975_GLOBE_R2016A_3857_38)
structured_data.data_format: Implied raster data (GeoTIFF likely, given spatial resolutions and grid format)
structured_data.description: Multitemporal information layer on built-up presence derived from Landsat image collections (GLS1975, GLS1990, GLS2000, and ad-hoc Landsat 8 collection 2013/2014). Produced by means of Global Human Settlement Layer methodology in 2015.

structured_data.name: Copernicus 100 m Global Land Cover 2015-2019
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files via URL, Dataset viewer
structured_data.subsector: Emissions from land within the city boundary
structured_data.description: Annual land cover maps representing detailed (100x100 m) spatial information on different types (classes) of physical coverage of the Earth's surface, e.g. forests, grasslands, croplands, lakes, wetlands. The product also includes continuous field layers or “fraction maps” for all basic land cover classes. Produced as part of the Copernicus global land monitoring service, with long-term continuity ensured by the European Commission and EU member states. Updated October 2024, with annual updates planned.

structured_data.name: WorldPop Open Population Repository (WOPR) - BuildingClass
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query and direct download links for specific files
structured_data.granularity: Global (implied by 'Global population data sets' and country selection for specific datasets)
structured_data.data_format: Table with download links (likely GeoTIFF or similar for gridded data)
structured_data.description: The WorldPop Open Population Repository (WOPR) provides access to gridded population estimates and related data, including BuildingClass data, created using bespoke methods for individual countries. It offers final products as well as early experimental results. Global population datasets consistent across countries and years are also available from the WorldPop website.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Not explicitly stated for BuildingClass, but other data types mention ~100m

structured_data.name: Microsoft Global Building Footprints
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable GEOJSON files by Quadkey Partitions from GitHub, visualized via Tableau Public Dashboard
structured_data.granularity: Global, with specific coverage for countries like United States, India, Brazil, Japan, Africa, and regions like the Persian Gulf
structured_data.description: Microsoft Bing Maps has released 1.4 billion open building footprints, making building outlines freely available globally. The dataset spans from 2014 and has been gathered from high-quality sources like Maxar, Airbus, and IGN France imagery. It is available under the Open Database License (ODbL).

structured_data.name: A global dataset of annual urban extents (1992–2020) from harmonized nighttime lights
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable file from https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.16602224.v1
structured_data.description: A global dataset of annual urban extents from 1992 to 2020, generated using consistent nighttime light observations and a stepwise-partitioning framework. The dataset characterizes spatial extents associated with intensive human settlement and high-intensity socioeconomic activities, providing information to capture historical and future urbanization trajectories.

structured_data.name: A spatially-explicit harmonized global dataset of critical infrastructure
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF
structured_data.description: A first-of-its-kind globally harmonized spatial dataset for the representation of Critical Infrastructure (CI). It collects and harmonizes detailed geospatial data of the world’s main CI systems into a single geospatial database and develops the Critical Infrastructure Spatial Index (CISI). The CISI aggregates high-resolution geospatial OpenStreetMap (OSM) data of 39 CI types categorized under seven overarching CI systems. The dataset is rasterized into a harmonized and consistent dataset with resolutions of 0.10 × 0.10 and 0.25 × 0.25 degrees. It can be applied to explore the current landscape of CI, identify CI hotspots, and as exposure input for large-scale risk assessments.

structured_data.name: Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (TIF and OVR files)
structured_data.description: The Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL) project, supported by European Commission, Joint Research Centre, and Directorate-General for Regional and Urban Policy, produces new global spatial information, evidence-based analytics, and knowledge describing human presence on the planet. It processes satellite image data streams, census data, and crowd-sourced information to report objectively and systematically about the presence of population and built-up infrastructures. The project produces thematic information and analytical knowledge supporting EU regional urban policy and international post-2015 frameworks (Sustainable Development Goals, Global Urban Agenda, Climate Change, Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction). The collection consists of built-up (GHS-BUILT), population (GHS-POP) grids, and city model (GHS-SMOD). The project was created on 2018-12-14 and modified on 2023-04-13.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Varies by dataset, e.g., GHS-AGE (1975-2020), GHS-SMOD ARCTIC (1975-2030), GHS-BUILT-S ARCTIC (1975-2030), GHS-BUILT-H ARCTIC (2018), GHS-POP ARCTIC (1975-2030), GHS-BUILT-V ARCTIC (1975-2030), GHS-BUSS ARCTIC (1975-2030)

structured_data.name: GlobalMLBuildingFootprints
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files from GitHub repository
structured_data.description: Worldwide building footprints derived from satellite imagery, provided by Microsoft. The repository shows updates as recent as Feb 28, 2025.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Derived from satellite imagery, with updates as recent as Feb 28, 2025.

structured_data.name: OpenStreetMap (OSM) Data
structured_data.method_of_access: API (Overpass API, Geoapify Places API), direct download
structured_data.description: OpenStreetMap (OSM) is a global, editable map created and maintained by a vast community of contributors. It offers a diverse collection of geographic data, including detailed metadata about places such as the number of floors in a building, website URLs, and opening hours. Data is structured using nodes, ways, and relations, with attributes described by key-value tags. It is widely used by developers for high-quality mapping data.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Individual building polygons (implied by 'number of floors in a building' and 'building=yes' tag example)

structured_data.name: GHS built-up surface (R2023) - GHS-BUILT-S
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (single file or by tiles) via HTTP/FTP links
structured_data.data_format: GeoTIFF (implied by 'tiles' and 'shapefile' context, and common for gridded data)
structured_data.description: The GHS built-up surface (R2023) dataset (GHS-BUILT-S) provides information on built-up areas. It is an updated edition built using the GHS-SMOD R2023A dataset, split by country. It includes boundaries and city centroids in each zip file. The data is available for different epochs, resolutions, and coordinate systems. The current selection shown is for epoch 2030, resolution 100m, Mollweide coordinate system, and 'Total RES+NRES' classification. The dataset is provided by the GHSL (Global Human Settlement Layer) project, part of Copernicus emergency management service.

structured_data.name: GHS-BUILT-H R2022A - GHS building height, derived from AW3D30, SRTM30, and Sentinel2 composite (2018) - OBSOLETE RELEASE
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files via FTP links (GHS-BUILT-H_ANBH_GLOBE_R2022A, GHS-BUILT-H_AGBH_GLOBE_R2022A)
structured_data.description: The spatial raster dataset depicts the spatial distribution of the building heights as extracted from the filtering of a composite of global digital elevation models (DEM) and the filtering of satellite imagery using linear regression techniques. Input DEMs are ALOS World 3D - 30m (AW3D30, 2006-2011) and Shuttle Radar Topography Mission 30m (SRTM30, 2000). Building heights are updated using shadow markers from Sentinel2 image data composite of 2018 (GHS-composite-S2 R2020A). Data is published at 100m resolution in World Mollweide (EPSG:54009). Building height information is summarized as Average of the Gross Building Height (AGBH) and Average of the Net Building Height (ANBH). Provided by European Commission, Joint Research Centre (JRC). This is an OBSOLETE RELEASE.

structured_data.name: Project Homeland Critical Infrastructure Dependencies Data
structured_data.method_of_access: Demonstration of ArcGIS Knowledge, implying access through Esri's ArcGIS platform or similar geospatial analysis tools. Data itself is likely proprietary or requires specific access agreements with MITRE or federal partners.
structured_data.subsector: Commercial and Institutional Buildings and Facilities
structured_data.data_format: Spatial knowledge graph, geospatial layers (implied GeoTIFF for flood data, vector for infrastructure)
structured_data.description: Project Homeland, an ongoing effort by MITRE in collaboration with Esri, analyzes critical infrastructure dependencies and identifies system vulnerabilities to boost resilience against compounding threats like extreme weather events and cyber-attacks. It uses ArcGIS Knowledge to model spatial and non-spatial data, including hospitals, water pumps, electrical substations, and their interdependencies. A pilot scenario was conducted in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, simulating a historic April 2023 rainfall event to identify affected roadways, buildings, and utilities.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Individual building polygons (implied for infrastructure facilities), ≤10m for urban flood analysis (from CCRA framework context, applied to Fort Lauderdale pilot)
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Historic April 2023 rainfall event simulated; ongoing project

structured_data.name: WorldPop Open Spatial Demographic Data and Research
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface for data catalog, API access (WorldPop Program API, WOPR REST API)
structured_data.description: WorldPop provides open access spatial demographic datasets built using transparent approaches, focusing on high-resolution geospatial data on population distributions, demographic and dynamics. They develop peer-reviewed research and methods for the construction of these datasets. The data supports health and development applications, including addressing the Sustainable Development Goals. They offer global, regional, and bespoke country datasets, including new Global 2 Population Data for 2015 to 2030.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: High spatial resolution (implied, as they focus on 'high-resolution geospatial data')

structured_data.name: A GIS-based framework for high-level climate change risk assessment of critical infrastructure
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF
structured_data.description: This study presents a GIS-based framework for high-level climate change risk assessment of critical infrastructure, with a case study for Ireland. It includes an inventory of assets for transport, energy, water, and ICT sectors, and assesses their vulnerability to fluvial flood threat. The content mentions tables detailing lengths of national road sections and rail line sections, and number of rail stations at risk from flooding.

structured_data.name: OpenStreetMap Export
structured_data.method_of_access: web interface query
structured_data.description: OpenStreetMap allows users to export map data, which includes building footprints and other geographic features contributed by users globally. The content provided shows a web interface for map layers and export options.

structured_data.name: Google Open Buildings Data
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable file (too large for direct download, suggests filtering via Google Earth Engine or Colab notebook for specific regions)
structured_data.granularity: Global (can be filtered to regional/city level)
structured_data.data_format: CSV (implied by discussion of 'lines' and filtering)
structured_data.description: A dataset of building footprints provided by Google Open Buildings, available for global download. The file is very large (28 million lines mentioned) and users often need to filter it for specific regions or cities. Access is suggested via a Google Colab notebook for regional polygon selection or Google Earth Engine.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Individual building polygons (implied by 'building data' and 'building footprints')

structured_data.name: OpenStreetMap Building Shape Coordinates
structured_data.method_of_access: Overpass API
structured_data.description: A dataset of building shape coordinates from OpenStreetMap, accessible via the Overpass API. The data can be used for urban analysis research, such as measuring building areas and circumferences. The Overpass API can provide data extracts for specific areas.

structured_data.name: Global construction materials database and stock analysis of residential buildings between 1970-2050
structured_data.method_of_access: Purchase PDF, Access through organization, or view article preview on ScienceDirect. Data described as a 'database' and 'input for modelling' implying structured data.
structured_data.granularity: Global, divided into 26 regions (in compliance with IMAGE model)
structured_data.description: A global construction materials database and stock analysis of residential buildings from 1970 to 2050. It compiles material intensities for different building types, applied in a scenario analysis linked to SSP scenarios as implemented in the global climate model IMAGE. The database includes six construction materials in four dwelling types in urban and rural areas. It aims to fill a gap in consistent information about material stocks in the residential built environment at a global level and is intended for resource and climate policymaking and environmental impact assessment.

structured_data.name: USA Structures
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable Feature Layer from Esri Living Atlas
structured_data.description: The USA Structures dataset is a comprehensive inventory of structures larger than 450 square feet, developed by FEMA, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, and the U.S. Geological Survey. It includes building outlines, occupancy types (e.g., Residential, Commercial, Industrial), primary occupancy types (e.g., Single Family Residential, Restaurant, Hospital), and a Universal Unique Identifier (UUID) for each structure. The data is designed to support emergency management, disaster response, and recovery decision-making processes. As of December 2021, occupancy type and address information is available for all states and territories.
structured_data.temporal_coverage: As of December 2021 (data developed using various sources including Census Housing Unit data, HIFLD, LightBox parcel data)

structured_data.name: WorldPop Global Data Collection
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files via WorldPop website
structured_data.description: The WorldPop Global data collection provides high resolution, open and contemporary data on human population distributions, including estimates of numbers of people residing in each 100 x 100 m grid cell and their age/sex structures. It includes population surfaces for total populations (both adjusted to match UN national estimates, and left unadjusted) as well as breakdowns by age and sex classes. The data is produced by the University Of Southampton (UK), University Of Louisville (USA), Universite Libre De Bruxelles (Belgium) And Flowminder Foundation.

structured_data.name: A global product of 150-m urban building height based on spaceborne lidar
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable PDF of the article, data likely available through a repository (not explicitly stated but implied for a 'product')
structured_data.description: A 150-m global urban building heights dataset around 2020, created by combining spaceborne lidar (Global Ecosystem Dynamics Investigation, GEDI), multi-sourced data (Landsat-8, Sentinel-2, and Sentinel-1), and topographic data. The product aims to provide fine spatial resolution with details about spatial heterogeneity and flexibility of updating using GEDI samples as inputs.

structured_data.name: GHSL: Global built-up surface 1975-2030 (P2023A)
structured_data.method_of_access: API (Google Earth Engine), Downloadable via JRC website
structured_data.description: This raster dataset, provided by EC JRC, depicts the distribution of built-up surfaces, expressed in square metres per 100 m grid cell. It measures total built-up surface and non-residential built-up surface. Data are spatially-temporally interpolated or extrapolated from 1975 to 2030 in 5-year intervals.

structured_data.name: Combining readily available population and land cover maps to generate non-residential built-up labels to train Sentinel-2 image segmentation models
structured_data.method_of_access: View PDF, Download full issue (via ScienceDirect)
structured_data.subsector: Commercial and Institutional Buildings and Facilities
structured_data.description: This article describes a method for combining readily available population and land cover maps (ESA WorldCover 2020 and WorldPop 2020) to generate non-residential built-up labels for training Sentinel-2 image segmentation models. The study focuses on the detection of non-residential buildings and compares the proposed method with existing baselines like GHSL_NRES and CLC+EWC. The methodology involves using ancillary datasets to train a non-residential built-up Sentinel-2 image segmentation model.

structured_data.name: Microsoft Building Footprints Features
structured_data.method_of_access: Page Not Found - likely web interface or download from ArcGIS Hub
structured_data.description: The page for 'Microsoft Building Footprints Features' on ArcGIS Hub was not found, indicating it may have been moved or deleted. The original intent was likely to provide exposure building data for Global.

structured_data.name: GLObal Building heights for Urban Studies (UT-GLOBUS)
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable GeoPackage (.gpkg) and binary files from Zenodo, with instructions for conversion to GeoTIFF and compatibility with GIS platforms and programming languages.
structured_data.granularity: Major cities worldwide, building-level data, 1-km² grid cells for UCPs
structured_data.description: UT-GLOBUS is a dataset providing building heights and urban canopy parameters (UCPs) for major cities worldwide. It combines open-source spaceborne altimetry (ICESat-2 and GEDI) and coarse resolution urban canopy elevation data with a random forest model. The dataset is provided by researchers from The University of Texas at Austin, Indian Institute of Tropical Meteorology, Centro de Investigaciones Energéticas, Medioambientales y Tecnológicas, Purdue University West Lafayette, and NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research. It was published on May 9, 2024, and can be used for modeling urban hazards, climate simulations, and human thermal comfort.
structured_data.spatial_resolution: Building-level, 1-km² grid cells for UCPs, vector files for data coverage
structured_data.temporal_coverage: Published May 9, 2024 (v1), with updates planned as new city data is added.

structured_data.name: Open Building Data Platform
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query
structured_data.subsector: Residential Buildings, Commercial and Institutional Buildings and Facilities, Manufacturing Industries and Construction
structured_data.description: The Open Building Data Platform provides data-driven insights to enhance life cycle performance of buildings, manage carbon footprint, and develop decarbonization strategies. It focuses on resource use and carbon emissions throughout the whole life cycle of buildings and across global supply-chains. The platform uses a coordinated, open and scalable data model to enhance exchange and comparability of life cycle data. It includes data on Portfolio, Project, Floor Area, and GHG emissions (Life Cycle Stages) for buildings.

structured_data.name: Open Buildings
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable file (link provided on website)
structured_data.granularity: Global (Africa, South Asia, South-East Asia, Latin America and the Caribbean)
structured_data.description: A dataset of 1.8 billion building footprints derived from high-resolution satellite imagery to support social good applications. The dataset includes the polygon describing the building's footprint, a confidence score, and a Plus Code for the center of the building. It does not include information about building type, street address, or other details beyond geometry. The project is based in Google's Ghana office, focusing on Africa and the Global South. The current dataset is its 3rd version.

structured_data.name: Land Cover 2019 (raster 100 m), global, yearly – version 3
structured_data.method_of_access: Downloadable files (Geotiff), Copernicus Data Space Ecosystem (CDSE) via Copernicus Browser, S3 storage (EODATA), OData API, CSV resource
structured_data.description: Provides at global level spatial information on different types (classes) of physical coverage of the Earth's surface, e.g. forests, grasslands, croplands, lakes, wetlands for the 2019 base year. The data are updated annually and are available for the 2015-2019 years. Provided by Copernicus Global Land Service.

structured_data.name: EC3: Embodied Carbon in Construction Calculator and EPD Database
structured_data.method_of_access: Web interface query, online tool access, sign-up required for full access
structured_data.subsector: Commercial and Institutional Buildings and Facilities
structured_data.description: The EC3 (Embodied Carbon in Construction Calculator) tool and its underlying digitized EPD (Environmental Product Declaration) database provide data to encourage low-carbon specification and procurement for building and infrastructure projects. It helps users set achievable carbon reduction targets and identify low-carbon materials by leveraging a robust database of EPDs to set embodied carbon baselines and drive reductions. Provided by Building Transparency, a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization established in 2020.

decision_log.summary: CCRA plan for exposure/buildings (Global) with 15 structured queries.

queries_processed: Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL) built-up area data
Copernicus Global Land Cover built-up areas

decision_log.summary: This batch of documents is highly promising for 'buildings' exposure data. Several documents directly link to or describe global-scale, high-resolution building footprint and built-up area datasets from authoritative sources like Copernicus, Microsoft, and WorldPop. These datasets include attributes such as age, height, and temporal information, which are crucial for CCRA building exposure analysis. The resolution of many of these datasets (e.g., 38m, 100m) meets the specified requirement of 5km or finer.
decision_log.reasoning: Multiple documents provide direct access or clear pathways to high-resolution, global building and built-up area datasets, some with additional attributes like age and height, which are directly relevant to the 'buildings' exposure type for CCRA. These sources are highly authoritative (Copernicus, Microsoft, WorldPop, Nature publications). The resolutions mentioned (e.g., 38m, 100m) are well within the 5km or finer requirement. The 'no content available' documents and the general academic paper links are less directly useful for immediate data extraction but the others are excellent.

decision_log.summary: The extracted structured data provides a strong foundation for a global exposure buildings dataset. Several high-quality, globally comprehensive datasets are identified, including building footprints (Microsoft, Google, OSM), built-up area extents (GHSL, Copernicus), and some building height information. There are also promising leads for critical infrastructure and population distribution, which are crucial for a comprehensive exposure assessment. However, detailed socioeconomic vulnerability indicators and specific building characteristics (e.g., construction materials, age, occupancy beyond broad categories) are less consistently available at a global, granular level. The current data leans heavily towards spatial extent and location of buildings, with less detail on their attributes or the demographics within them.
decision_log.reasoning: The extracted data provides a very strong foundation for a global exposure buildings dataset. The presence of multiple high-resolution, globally comprehensive building footprint datasets (Microsoft, Google, OSM) is a significant achievement. Complementary datasets like GHSL and Copernicus provide valuable built-up area and temporal context. While some detailed attributes (e.g., construction materials, specific socioeconomic vulnerability indicators) are not universally available at a granular level, the core 'buildings exposure' (location, extent, some height) is well-covered by highly credible sources. The identified datasets are suitable for quantitative risk assessment, meeting the spatial resolution and format requirements. Further refinement for specific attributes can be pursued in subsequent steps if needed, but the current collection is sufficient to proceed with initial exposure mapping.

search_plan_summary.query: Global Human Settlement Layer (GHSL) built-up area data
Copernicus Global Land Cover built-up areas
Global exposure database for disaster risk reduction
